discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Add a CPU limit to the vSphere Namespace for the development team.

To manage the potential impact of CPU-intensive applications on other teams within a vSphere Namespace, setting a CPU limit specifically for the vSphere Namespace associated with the development team is a reasonable approach. This ensures that the CPU usage of the applications within that Namespace is restricted to a defined limit, preventing them from consuming excessive resources and impacting other workloads in the same environment.

Setting a CPU limit directly on the Namespace provides a level of resource isolation for the development team, allowing them to conduct their tests without adversely affecting other teams sharing the same vSphere infrastructure.

Selected Answer: D
D. B cannot be correct.

Selected Answer: D
I will go with D, here's why: 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-A555F1AC-2338-46EA-A1BA-A71091ED9CA8.html

From the article:

1. From the vSphere Client home menu, select Workload Management.
2. Select a vSphere Namespace, select Configure, and click Resource Limits.
3. Click Edit
4. Set a limit to the CPU consumption on the vSphere Namespace.

choices.D: Add a CPU limit to the vSphere Namespace for the development team.
choices.B: Add a CPU limit to the Namespace Resource Pool in vCenter.
choices.A: Set a CPU reservation on the Namespace Resource Pool in vCenter.
choices.C: Set a network policy to limit network bandwidth within the vSphere Namespace.

questions.question_text:
The application development team plans to test a few CPU intensive applications. The virtualization team is concerned about these applications impacting other teams.

How should the team manage this problem?

An administrator needs to limit resource consumption within a vSphere with Tanzu namespace.

Which three actions should be taken to meet this goal? (Choose three.)

choices.A: Limit the capacity of the storage able to be consumed.
choices.F: Limit the number of vSphere Pods able to be provisioned.
choices.C: Limit the number of load balancers able to be deployed.
choices.E: Limit the number of Operators able to be deployed.
choices.D: Limit the CPU and Memory able to be consumed.
choices.B: Change the size of the Supervisor Control Plane nodes.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADF
With these questions it's easier to eliminate the wrong answers than to pick the correct ones. It's easier to find the wrong answers. Let's see:

B. Change the size of the Supervisor Control Plane nodes. - Supervisor node? Not even the right ballpark, we're talking about the namespace.
C. Limit the number of load balancers able to be deployed. - What does this have to do with capacity? It would make only a tiny difference. And load balancers are structural, you have to have the ones you need, you don't deploy spare ones for fun.
E. Limit the number of Operators able to be deployed. - Less people administering the environment will reduce capacity demand? Give me a break!

So you can see those are easy to eliminate, and that leaves A, D, F as reasonable answers. Easy!

questions.question_text: Which capability do persistent volumes provide to containerized applications?

discussion.content: D. Retention of application state and data

Selected Answer: D
Of course it's D)

A. Automated disk archival - Persistent disks have nothing to do with archiving data

B. Support for in-memory databases - What does disk storage have to do with memory? These aren't pagefiles. 

C. Support for ephemeral workloads - Ephemeral workloads are, well, ephemeral and thus don't need persistent storage

D. Retention of application state and data - Obviously the correct answer.

What I want to know is how the official Examtopics answer for this could be so wrong!

Selected Answer: D
D. Persistent volumes are defined by a PVC (Persistent Volume Claim) in a manifest file which is for maintaining state if a container is lost

choices.D: Retention of application state and data

choices.B: Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs are attached to primary and non-primary workload networks.
choices.C: vCenter Server is attached to all workload networks.
choices.D: Load balancer appliance is attached to all workload networks.
choices.A: Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs are attached to the primary workload network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Check the doc obeythefist links.

Selected Answer: A
I believe this is "A". 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-B156CDA6-B056-4D1C-BBC5-07D1A701E402.html

> The network that provides connectivity to the Kubernetes Control Plane VMs is called Primary Workload Network
A Supervisor Cluster control plane VMs are attached to the primary workload network.

questions.question_text: Which statement describes the characteristics of vSphere with Tanzu using vSphere Distributed Switch network topology?
Which two actions are orchestrated by the NSX Container Plugin (NCP)? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
D&E. No other answers make sense.

Selected Answer: DE
I will go with D and E for this. 

NCP absolutely oversees creation of services (by which we mean a port for access), so D is straightforward.

This article: 

https://www.jamesmcleod.xyz/2020/10/21/ncp-networkpolicies/

Goes into how NCP oversees creation of network policies by taking them and implementing the relevant objects and network configurations so they will work. That makes "E" a compelling answer.
